ground_truth_articulation: Classify as true if the input contains a URL pattern starting with 'http' or 'www'.
generated_articulation: The output is True when the input contains at least one URL (starting with "http://" or "https://", or "www.") and includes at least one of the words "check," "function," "result," or "the"; otherwise, it is False.
raw_response: The output is True when the input contains at least one URL (starting with "http://" or "https://", or "www.") and includes at least one of the words "check," "function," "result," or "the"; otherwise, it is False.
llm_judge_reasoning: The ground truth rule classifies inputs as true solely based on the presence of a URL starting with "http" or "www", regardless of other content. The generated rule adds additional conditions: the URL must start with "http://", "https://", or "www.", and the input must also contain at least one of the words "check," "function," "result," or "the". This makes the generated rule more restrictive and context-dependent. While both rules focus on URLs, the generated rule incorporates extra textual conditions, leading to potential differences in classification. They share the core idea of identifying URLs, but the added constraints mean they are not equivalent in logic.
